Information package structure

ASTA is the Danish National Archives’ support tool for the submission of data from statistics files to the archives.

You can download the latest version of ASTA and useful guidance documents from the website of the Danish National Archives.

Data from statistics files must be submitted in the form of an information package.

You can use ASTA to create extractions from statistics files in SAS, Stata, SPSS or R formats for an information package and to test whether or not your information package complies with the specific requirements for information packages set out in Schedule 9 of the Executive Order on Information Packages no 128.

FAQs
FAQs – Frequently Asked Questions
What is an information package?

When submitting data from statistics files to the archives, you must do this in the form of an information package.

Folder structure and content of an information package:
What requirements does an information package need to meet?

An information package containing data from statistics files needs to meet certain requirements relating to folder structure, the naming of folders and files, data types, codes for missing values, etc.

All of the relevant requirements are set out in Schedule 9 of the Executive Order on Information Packages no 128.

An easy-to-read version of the requirements set out in Schedule 9 on data quality and documentation can be found under Guidance in the section "How to quality-assure the statistics file before extraction".
What types of data can be submitted to the archives in the form of an information package?

Data created in connection with research using scientific methods and created or processed in statistics programs, etc. can be submitted as an information package in accordance with the rules in Schedule 9 of the Executive Order on Information Packages no 128.

The submission provision that you will have received from the archives in connection with your submission case will state whether data is to be submitted as an information package.

Data created or stored in databases and qualitative interviews and other document collections must be submitted in accordance with the rules set out in Schedules 1–8 of the Executive Order on Information Packages no 128.
How do I create an information package?

You can use the "Create information package" function in ASTA to create parts of an information package.

You can also create an information package yourself without using ASTA; for example by contracting a supplier to convert your statistics files and documentation into an information package.
What does the "Create information package" function do?

The "Create information package" function is an extraction tool which can be used to create parts of an information package.

You can use this extraction tool to:

  • Create an empty folder structure for the information package.
  • Create data and metadata extractions from your statistics files which comply with the requirements for the structure of data and metadata files in an information package.
  • Place the index files in the information package
  • Place context documentation in the information package in accordance with the order set out in the index file contextDocumentationIndex.xml
What does the "Test information package" function do?

The "Test information package" function can be used to test whether or not an information package complies with the requirements in Schedule 9 of the Executive Order on Information Packages no 128.

Once an information package is tested using the "Test information package" function, a test log will be automatically saved at the same destination as the tested information package.
Where can I find help and guidance?

You can find a quick guide under the Guidance tab as well as instructions on how to produce an information package.

You will also look under the Help tab for guidance on how to correct errors shown in a test log after an information package has been tested
Help
Help with error identification and reporting
Help understanding errors in the ASTA test log following an information package test

When you test an information package using the "Test information package" function in ASTA, an ASTA test log will be automatically created.
The HTML version of the ASTA test log will display an error ID (e.g. 15700) for each error message.
Clicking on the error ID will bring up the following:
  1. Guidance on how to correct the error
  2. Example which complies with the requirements in Schedule 9
  3. Specification of the requirements in Schedule 9 that the error concerns
Reporting problems with ASTA

If ASTA closes unexpectedly and displays a system error message which prevents you from completing the information package, you can report the error to the Danish National Archives. Take a print screen of the error message and send it to us together with the ASTA_systemlog file and a detailed description of what caused the error or in what part of the program it occurred.

Send your error report to mailbox@sa.dk, FAO: Data Manager for Research Data.

System log files

ASTA generates the system log file [ASTA_systemlog.log] which is placed in the folder

General path for system log files:
macOS: ~/Library/Logs/asta/ASTA_systemlog.log
Windows: Users\%USERPROFILE%\AppData\Roaming\asta\ASTA_systemlog.log
System requirements when using ASTA

Errors in ASTA may also be due to your computer or software not meeting the system requirements to run ASTA.

Below you can check which operating systems, web browsers and versions of statistics programs that ASTA has been tested to run on.
If you use another operating system, web browser or version of a statistics program, there is no guarantee that ASTA will function correctly.

Operating systems:
ASTA has been tested for the following operating systems:

  • Windows 7 and 10
  • macOS High Sierra

Web browsers:
The test log displaying guidance under error IDs will work on the following browsers:

  • Google Chrome version 77.0.3865.90 (Official Version) (64-bit)
  • Mozilla Firefox, version 69.0.2 (64-bit)
  • Microsoft Internet Explorer 11 [Remember to allow blocked content in order to view error IDs]
  • Microsoft Edge, version 17.17134
  • Safari version 11.1.2 (13605.3.8)

Statistics programs
The export of scripts for the extraction of data and metadata from statistics files can be executed in the following versions of the statistics programs

  • SAS v. 9.4
  • SPSS v. 24
  • Stata v. 14.2
  • RStudio v. 1.2.5033

Other system requirements

  • Optimal screen resolution is 1920 x 1080 or 1920 x 1200. Some buttons may not be visible in ASTA if a lower resolution is used.
  • As ASTA is installed on your computer, you must have administrator rights for your computer in order to run the program.
Clearing up your computer after using ASTA

Using ASTA will result in a range of files and programs being saved on your computer.
  • ASTA is installed as a software program on your computer. Delete the program from your computer.

  • ASTA automatically creates a shortcut to the program on your desktop when you install the program. Delete this shortcut.

  • Using ASTA will result in a range of system log files and a profile being saved on your computer. You can delete these by deleting the folder entitled "asta" at the following location:

    • macOS: ~/Library/Logs/
    Windows: Users\%USERPROFILE%\AppData\Roaming\

  • Using ASTA will result in a number of test logs, scripts and script logs being saved on your computer at the same destination as the original statistics file selected. We recommend that you work within a single folder when using ASTA. That way you can clear up afterwards simply by deleting this entire folder.

    • Note! Do not delete files created by ASTA until your submission has been approved by the archives
Guidance
Quick guide on the creation and testing of an information package
How to quality-assure the statistics file before extraction

The Danish National Archives has created the ASTA tool (Submission of Statistics to the Archives as per its Danish initials) so that you can create and test information packages which contain data extracted from statistics files and which comply with the archives’ requirements for information packages. These requirements are set out in Schedule 9 of the Executive Order on Information Packages no 128. The Executive Order and related guidance can be found at the archives’ website: www.sa.dk.

When you create an information package with ASTA, the program will check that the information package complies with the structural requirements for folder structure and data and metadata files. However, you must also check yourself that the data and metadata content in the statistics files complies with the requirements in Schedule 9 before using ASTA to extract data.

The "Create information package" function in ASTA only extracts data and metadata found in the statistics file.
It is therefore important you ensure that the quality of data and metadata in the statistics file complies with the archives’ requirements in Schedule 9 of the Executive Order on Information Packages no 128 before using ASTA to extract data.

The requirements on data and metadata quality are listed below.

Data file

  • The character set for the statistics file must be encoded as UTF-8. See guidance on UTF-8 on the website of the Danish National Archives.

Variable

  • Line breaks are not permitted in the content of variables.
  • Variable names must be specified for all variables.
  • Variable names may never begin with a number, but they can be a mix of letters and numbers.
  • Variable names may not be longer than 128 characters.
  • Variable descriptions [Variable labels] must be specified for all variables.

Data types (Formats)

  • Data types for variables in the statistics file must comply with the data types permitted in an information package as specified in Figure 9.3 of Schedule 9 of the Executive Order on Information Packages no 128. If this is not the case, then you must yourself convert the data types to the permitted formats before using ASTA to extract data.

Value labels/Formats

  • All code values in data [Values] must be described by a code explanation [Value labels]
  • Code lists [Value labels] may only be attached to numerical and categorical variables with the data types numeric integer, decimal and text.
  • Codes [Values] must be unique within the same code list [Value labels attached to a variable]

Codes for missing values

  • Special codes for missing values (SAS and Stata) may only have the values A-Z or .a-.z.
  • Special codes (SAS and Stata) for missing values must only be used for numerical and categorical variables with the data types numeric integer and decimal
  • User-defined codes (SPSS) for missing values must only be used for numerical and categorical variables with the data types numeric integer, decimal and text
  • Missing values must be represented consistently and only by either special codes (.a-.z or A-Z) or by user-defined codes
  • If user-defined codes (SPSS) for missing values are used for variables with the data type date or time stamp, then this must be described in a context document in the information package.
  • Both special codes and user-defined codes for missing values in a variable must always appear in the code list [Value labels] for that variable
  • If code explanations [Value labels] are only specified for some of the codes [Values] that appear in a scale, then this must be described in the variable description for the variable in question.

Merge variables (references)

  • There must be complete consistency between the data type and length for merge variables which are included in a reference between multiple statistics files in the information package

</br>Read the manual for Schedule 9 of the Executive Order on Information Packages no 128 for a more detailed description of what an information package is and what requirements are placed on the data and metadata file. You find the manual for Schedule 9 of the Executive Order on Information Packages no 128 on the website of the Danish National Archives.

You will need to have the following things ready before you can create an information package with ASTA

As it is not possible to undo actions or navigate backwards in ASTA, you must have the below files and information ready before beginning to create an information package with ASTA.

You can subsequently add or replace existing index files and context documents in an information package by using the "Edit information package" function.

  • Retrieve the statistics files to be submitted to the archives.
    • Note! If personal data is separated from the statistics file in a key file, then both the statistics file and the key file should be included in the information package
  • Retrieve the serial number for the information package. Serial numbers are provided by the archives and will be stated in your submission provision.

  • Complete the index files archiveIndex.xml and contextDocumentationIndex.xml. The archives have developed special input tools for the completion of index files. View the guidance documents for these tools on the website of the Danish National Archives: www.sa.dk.
    • Note! The archives must approve the completed index files before you place them in the information package
  • Retrieve the context documents to be included in the information package. These are stated in the submission provision.

  • Convert the context documents into their preservation formats; e.g. .tif (documents and images), .mp3 (audio files) and .mpg (video). See a guidance document on TIFF conversion on the website of the Danish National Archives: www.sa.dk.
    • Note! You can still convert context documents even after the information package has been created using ASTA
  • Clarify whether there are any unique variables in the statistics files which need to be specified as key variables during extraction via ASTA.

  • Clarify whether there are any merge variables across statistics files in the information package which need to be specified in a mark-up of references during extraction via ASTA and over which variables these references need to be generated.
You can create the following parts of the information package with ASTA

Use the "Create information package" function to do the following:
  • Name the information package with the correct serial number.
  • Generate an empty folder structure for the information package with a structure and folder names which comply with the requirements set out in Schedule 9.
  • Create data and metadata extractions from your original statistics files for data and metadata which comply with the structural requirements for such files as set out in Schedule 9.
  • Add archiveIndex.xml and contextDocumentationIndex.xml to the information package. See the guidance documents for the tools for completion of index files for guidance on completing these index files.
  • Add context documents to the information package.
You will need to prepare the following parts of the information package yourself

You cannot use ASTA to do the following:
  • Complete index files
  • Convert context documents into their preservation format; e.g. .tif or .mp3
How to check whether extractions made using ASTA are lossless

It is important that the data submitted to the Danish National Archives is authentic and corresponds to the content in the original statistics files. It is the responsibility of the submitting authority to ensure that the extraction made using ASTA or any other tool is lossless. You should perform a visual check of the data before and after conversion and you should also check whether the metadata in the metadata file (e.g. table1.txt) has been extracted correctly and free of loss from the original statistics file.
How to test an information package

Use the "Test information package" function:
  • Select the information package you want to test and click on the "Start test" button
  • Read any error messages shown in the test log
  • Click on the error ID in the HTML version of the test log which will appear when you click the "Show log" button in order to see guidance on how to correct the error
  • Correct the errors shown in the test log and test the information package again
  • Once the information package has been tested without errors then it can be submitted to the archives in accordance with the rules for submission which can be found on the archives’ website: www.sa.dk
How to correct errors in an existing information package

• Errors in the data and metadata files can be corrected directly in the statistics file before then using ASTA to create a new extraction.

    • If the error cannot be corrected in the statistics file, then it is permitted to correct the error directly in the data file (e.g. table1.csv) and the metadata file (e.g. table1.txt) extracted from the statistics file. However, these errors should be corrected last, once you are sure that there are no other errors to be corrected by creating a new extraction from the statistics file.

  • Errors in the index files can be corrected in the archives’ input tools for these. These tools validate whether or not the files comply with the requirements for index files. Changes to the index files must be approved by the archives.

  • Errors in context documents can be corrected by replacing the existing context document with a corrected version.

    • Note! If new context documents (which do not appear on the submission provision) are added to the information package, then the submission provision must be updated to include these documents and be approved by the archives

Checklist

You should be sure to have the following things ready before you create an information package:

  1. Serial number for information package – the serial number is provided by the archives and can be found on your submission provision

  2. The statistics files to be included in the information package and submitted to the archives – remember to quality-assure the statistics files before extraction
    3. Warning! Always use a COPY of your original statistics file!
  3. The index files archiveIndex.xml and contextDocumentationIndex.xml

  4. The context documents to be included in the information package. The context documents must be converted to TIFF, JPEG-2000, MP3, WAVE or MPEG before they are submitted to the archives

  5. Description of the statistics files’ content

  6. Clarify key variables – which unique variables in the statistics files are to be declared as key variables?

  7. Clarify references – over which variables are references created and between which statistics files in the information package?
See Guidance for more guidance as to how you can quality-assure the statistics file and prepare other documents for extraction via ASTA.

Extract data from the statistics file

You can extract data and metadata from your statistic files into an information package here

The extraction process consists of three steps for each statistics file:
STEP 1: Select statistics file
STEP 2: Run the export script in your statistics program
STEP 3: Enter information on the statistics file

Note! You can only create extractions from statistics files in the formats SPSS, SAS, Stata or R.
STEP 1: Select the statistics file that the extract is to be made from:
Select statistics file

Select the statistics file you want to make an extraction from. The file must have one of the following formats: .sas7bdat (SAS file), .dta (Stata file), .sav (SPSS file) or .rds (R file). When extracting data from an SAS file with a catalogue, the catalogue file (.sas7bcat) must be placed in the same folder as the SAS data file (.sas7bdat) that the extraction is being made from and given the same name as the data file. You must make a copy of the catalogue file and rename it accordingly.

Copying of files for extraction check

Here you can make copies of files which you can then use to check that the extractions made using ASTA are lossless and to support the work of the archives in testing and approving the information package.
The files are copied to the folder ASTA_KONTROLFILER_FD.XXXXX which is placed beside the information package created.

You can make a copy of the following files:
  1. Your original statistics file
  2. The export script used for extraction
  3. Any output files from the extraction (SPSS only)
  4. The file statisticsfilename_Exportscriptlog.spv (SPSS only). The file contains the result of the comparison between the original statistics file and the output file from the extraction in SPSS.
Note! The folder ASTA_kontrolfiler_FD.XXXXX can conveniently be submitted to the archives together with the information package

Requirements in Schedule 9

9.I. Metadata file
9.I.1 Metadata from a data file is submitted as a structured text file that complies with the syntax described as EBNF in Figure 9.11.

9.I. Metadata file
9.I.1 Metadata from a data file is submitted as a structured text file that complies with the syntax described as EBNF in Figure 9.11.

EBNF in Figure 9.11:
KEY VARIABLE ::= ”NØGLEVARIABEL” LINEBREAK {VARIABLENAME SPACE} LINEBREAK {LINEBREAK}
VARIABLENAME ::=TITLE
TITLE ::=(LETTER {LETTER | DIGIT}) | (QUOTATIONMARK LETTER {LETTER | DIGIT} QUOTATIONMARK)!! A TITLE must never begin with a number, but can be a mix of letters and numbers up to a maximum of 128 characters, and if the title is a reserved word in SQL: 1999, then the title must be enclosed by double quotation marks; cf. ISO/IEC 9075:1999 – Database Language SQL (SQL:99)

Figure 9.4 The structure of the metadata file
KEY VARIABLE: The unique key variable of the data file is specified with the names of the variable(s) that the key variable consists of.
Outcome space: ISO/IEC 9075:1999 – Database Language SQL (SQL-99)
Cardinality: 0–1.
Mandatory: Yes, if a unique key variable exists.
The variable {1} included in the key variable specified under the tag KEY VARIABLE in the metadata file {0} begins with a number

Guidance

Rename the key variable so that it does not contain any illegal characters.
Illegal characters are all characters other than numbers and letters.
Spaces and white space characters are not allowed.
A key variable must consist of a single word without spaces.
In a composite key variable consisting of multiple key variables, the different key variables must be separated by spaces.
A key variable may never begin with a number but can be a mix of letters and numbers up to a maximum of 128 characters.
If the key variable specified is a reserved word in SQL:1999, then the key variable must be enclosed by double quotation marks.

Example

KEY VARIABLE
date of birth lbnr "select"

9.I.3.a A reference to another data file in the information package is specified by the name of the data file referenced (foreign data file), followed by the variable name of the foreign data file’s key variable (foreign variable) followed by the variable name of the variable (reference variable) in the data file, which refers to the foreign variable in the foreign data file.

9.I. Metadata file
9.I.1 Metadata from a data file is submitted as a structured text file that complies with the syntax described as EBNF in Figure 9.11.

EBNF in Figure 9.11:
REFERENCE ::= ”REFERENCE” LINEBREAK {FOREIGNDATAFILE SPACE FOREIGNVARIABLE SPACE REFERENCEVARIABLE LINEBREAK} LINEBREAK
FOREIGNDATAFILE ::= TITLE !! name of the data file referenced
FOREIGNVARIABLE ::=APOSTROPHE VARIABLENAME {SPACE VARIABLENAME} APOSTROPHE !! name of the key variable in the referenced data file
REFERENCEVARIABLE ::=APOSTROPHE VARIABLENAME {SPACE VARIABLENAME} APOSTROPHE !! name of the variable in the referenced data file, which refers to the key variable in the referenced data file
TITLE ::=(LETTER {LETTER | DIGIT}) | (QUOTATIONMARK LETTER {LETTER | DIGIT} QUOTATIONMARK)!! A TITLE must never begin with a number, but can be a mix of letters and numbers up to a maximum of 128 characters, and if the title is a reserved word in SQL: 1999, then the title must be enclosed by double quotation marks; cf. ISO/IEC 9075:1999 – Database Language SQL (SQL:99)
The foreign data file {1} specified under the tag REFERENCE in the metadata file {0} cannot be found in the information package

Guidance

The foreign variable declared as the second item of information under the tag REFERENCE in the metadata file must be found in the metadata file for the foreign data file being referenced.

Example

REFERENCE
datafile2 'cpr_2' 'cpr_1'

Specification in the metadata file for the foreign data file datafil2:
VARIABLE
cpr_2 f10
name a200
siblings f2
...

Guidance

Enter a permitted data format notation.
The data format notation specified for the variable in the metadata file must correspond to the data content in the data file for the variable concerned.
Use the statistics program to convert to one of the permitted data formats before extracting to the information package.

The six standardised data types that may be used in the data file are text, numeric integers, decimal numbers, dates, times and time stamps.
The permitted data format notations, which must be specified in the metadata file under the tag VARIABLE, are, cf. Figure 9.3, as follows:

Text
1. string
2. %ws
3. $w.
4. aw

Numeric integer [e.g. 23 and 10000 and -100 and +34]
1. int
2. %w.0f
3. fw.
4. fw

Decimal numbers [e.g. +0.4 and -500,12 and 8.10 and 10000.50 and .23 and 10]
1. decimal
2. %w.df or %w.dg
3. fw.d
4. fw.d

Date [CCYY-MM-DD, e.g. 2018-12-24]
1. date
2. %tdCCYY-NN-DD
3. yymmdd. or yymmdd10.
4. sdate10 [CCYY/MM/DD, e.g. 2018/12/24]

Time [hh:mm:ss, e.g. 13:10:04]
1. time
2. %tcHH:MM:SS
3. time. or time8.
4. time8

Time stamp [CCYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss.sss e.g. 2018-12-24T13:10:04.123456 or CCYY-MM-DD hh:mm:ss.sss e.g. 2018-12-24 13:10:04.123456. Fractional seconds are optional and are allowed with a precision of up to 6 digits.]
1. datetime
2. %tcCCYY-NN-DD!THH:MM:SS.sss
3. e8601dt19. or e8601dtw.d
4. datetime20 [dd-mmm-yyyy hh:mm:ss, e.g. 24-DEC-2018 30:10:04] or ymdhms19 [yyyy-mm-dd hh:mm:ss, e.g. 2018-12-24 30:10:04] or ymdhmsw.d [yyyy-mm-dd hh:mm:ss.sss, e.g. 2018-12-24 30:10:04.123456]

Example

VARIABLE
name a765
age f3
gender f3
date of birth sdate10
time of birth time8
weight f3.1
bloodsample_timestamp datetime20

Data file
name;age;gender;dateofbirth;timeofbirth;weight;bloodsample_timestamp
Mette Hansen;29;1;2019/01/09;15:31:22;5.6;09-JAN-2019 17:08:13
Anna Jensen;31;2;2019/01/14;22:52:23;5.2;14-JAN-2019 23:10:10

Guidance

If there are no formats/value labels attached to the statistics file’s variables, then you can ignore this hint.

However, the hint may also be due to the following errors which must be corrected:

1) If the data has been extracted from an SAS file which is attached to a catalogue file (format file) created on another operating system or in another version of the SAS program than the one used to extract data via ASTA, then the formats from the catalogue file will not be read by the SAS program during extraction and thus they will not be extracted to the metadata file in the information package. This error can be corrected by recreating the catalogue file on a more recent operating system and/or in a more recent version of SAS.

2) There are formats for the statistics file’s variables, but for another reason these have not been extracted or do not exist. This must also be corrected. All codes in the data file must be explained in a code list in the metadata file.

Guidance

A row under the tag USER CODE must consist of a variable name followed by at least one user-defined code.
The user-defined codes must each be enclosed by single quotation marks.

A user-defined code for a missing value is a code which users have defined themselves.
A user-defined code typically indicates why a value in a field is missing.

User-defined codes are often used in the statistics program SPSS, while standard defined codes (special codes) such as .i and .u or I and U are used in the statistics programs STATA and SAS.
It is only the user-defined codes for missing values that should be specified under the tag USER CODE, and not these special codes.

Example

USER CODE
Hobby '9'
Occupation '9' '10'
Education '9'

Examples of user codes:
9 = undisclosed (which indicates that a respondent in a survey has not answered the question even though they were supposed to)
10 = irrelevant (which indicates that the respondent has not answered the question because they weren’t supposed to due to a filter in the survey)

9.G.1 The data file is submitted as a semicolon separated text file according to RCF 4180 Common Format and MIME Type for CSV Files that adheres to the syntax described as EBNF in Figure 9.12.

Figur 9.12 EBNF Syntax rules for data files
DATAFILE ::= DATA CONTENT
DATACONTENT ::= HEADING LINEBREAK ROW {ROW}
HEADING ::= VARIABLENAME {SEPARATORCHARACTER VARIABLENAME}!! A separator character is not used after the last variable name in the heading line
SEPARATORCHARACTER ::= ”;” !! semicolon (U+003B)
ROW ::= VALUE | (QUOTATIONMARK VALUE QUOTATIONMARK) {SEPARATORCHARACTER VALUE | (QUOTATIONMARK VALUE QUOTATIONMARK)} LINEBREAK !! A separator character is not used after the last value in a row. See 9.G.1.b for enclosing a value containing separator characters and/or double quotation marks
The data file {0} uses the wrong separator character

Guidance

The fact that there are too many or too few semicolons in the data file means that the number of values in a line of the data file does not correspond with the number of variable names declared in the first line of the data file.
All lines of the data file must have the same number of semicolons as the number of variables in the data file minus 1.

A semicolon (U+003B) must be used as the separator character in the data file.
If a semicolon is included in a value for a variable, the whole value must be enclosed in double quotation marks.
A separator character is not used after the last variable value in a line.
A separator character is not used after the last variable name in the first line of the data file.
Elements which corresponds to rows/respondents in the statistics file must be separated by line breaks in the data file.
Content in variables in the data file must not contain line breaks.

This error occurs in the following cases:
1) If a semicolon is included in a value (text) and the whole value is not enclosed in double quotation marks.
2) If there is a line break in the value of the data file.
3) If there is a separator character (semicolon) after the last value in a row.
4) If the data file does not contain any line breaks and all values in the data file are in the first line.

Example

gender;timeofbirth;weight;comment
1;30-MAR-2002 15:31:22;5.6;Cesarean
1;09-MAY-2003 10:15:55;5.2;"Twins; boy and girl"

If the variable is categorical, then all codes must be explained in a code list.
If the variable is numerical but contains codes for missing values, then only the codes for missing values should be explained in a code list.
Both special codes (missing values in SAS [A-Z] and Stata [.a-.z]) and user-defined codes for missing values (missing values in SPSS [e.g. -999]) need to be explained in the code list for the variable where the code is used.

NB: Test 15700 stops after 10 errors found. There may therefore be more codes in the data file that are missing a code description even if they are not shown in the test log.
NB: Empty values in the data file must not be indicated using codes such as NA, NaN, NULL and full stop or similar; instead they should always be indicated by an empty field or a space.

DD ::= DIGIT DIGIT !! day is indicated by two integers

Guidance

If a double quotation mark is included in a value for a variable, the double quotation mark must be preceded by a double quotation mark and the entire value is enclosed in double quotation marks.

Example

E.g. The girl was a stargazer born with her face turned "towards the stars" (the ceiling) would be extracted as "The girl was a stargazer born with her face turned ""towards the stars"" (the ceiling)" in the data file.
E.g. "She said: "Hello to you"" would be extracted as """She said: ""Hello to you""""" in the data file.
E.g. "He said; "Hey, you"" would be extracted as """He said; ""Hey, you""""" in the data file.
